procedure: Right hip open reduction internal fixation (ORIF)
Appendectomy (past procedure)
Right hip open reduction internal fixation (ORIF)
Appendectomy (past procedure)
extracted_info.summary: 81-year-old female admitted following a mechanical fall resulting in a comminuted intertrochanteric fracture of the right hip. Patient is unable to bear weight and has pain with movement. Patient has history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and vasculitis. Plan is for surgical intervention with right hip ORIF.
key_information: Patient suffered mechanical fall with no loss of consciousness
Patient is at baseline mental status
Code status: Full Code
CT shows degenerative changes of lumbar spine without acute fracture
Chest X-ray without evidence of active pleural or parenchymal disease
Patient has shortened and externally rotated right hip
Patient is unable to straight leg raise due to pain
Patient has 2+ DP/PT pulses and intact distal neurovascular status
EKG shows NSR with Left bundle branch block
Patient is on insulin therapy for diabetes
Patient and son were informed of surgical risks and benefits
Non-operative management deemed inappropriate due to patient's independent mobility status

procedure: Right hip open reduction internal fixation
Intramedullary nailing of the femur
extracted_info.summary: 81-year-old female who suffered a mechanical fall resulting in a displaced right intertrochanteric femur fracture. Patient underwent open reduction internal fixation with an Arthrex intramedullary nail (10mm short 130 degree nail, 95mm lag screw, 36mm interlocking screw). Procedure was performed under spinal anesthesia with an estimated blood loss of 150mL.
key_information: Surgery date: 10/09/2025
Surgeon: Dr. Kevin J Choo
Anesthesia: Spinal
EBL: 150mL
Implants: Arthrex Nail (10mm short 130 degree nail, 95mm lag screw, 36mm interlocking screw)
Post-op plan: WBAT (protected weight bearing with walker)
DVT prophylaxis: aspirin starting POD1, SCDs, compression stockings, progressive mobilization
24 hours of postoperative antibiotics
Tranexamic acid 1 gram administered during procedure
MRN: MR598089
Location: Greenwich Hospital

documentation: Function-limiting pain for at least six (6) months in duration (Evidence: pg no: 4, L156-L157)
Abnormal shoulder physical examination findings compared to non-involved side including functionally limited range of motion or measurable loss in strength (Evidence: pg no: 4, L158-L161)
Positive Neer Impingement Test or Hawkins-Kennedy Impingement Test (Evidence: pg no: 4, L162)
Failure of provider-directed non-surgical management for at least three (3) months in duration (Evidence: pg no: 4, L163-L164)
Advanced diagnostic imaging study (e.g., MRI, CT) is inconclusive for internal derangement/pathology (Evidence: pg no: 4, L165)

Other potential pathological conditions have been excluded including fracture, thoracic outlet syndrome, brachial plexus disorders, referred neck pain and advanced glenohumeral osteoarthritis (Evidence: pg no: 4, L166-L168)

exclusions: Any other indication or condition (Evidence: pg no: 5, L171-L172)
In-office diagnostic arthroscopy (e.g., Mi-Eye™, VisionScope®) - considered experimental, investigational, or unproven (Evidence: pg no: 5, L175-L176)

documentation: Function-limiting pain (Evidence: pg no: 10, L410-L412)

Other potential pathological conditions have been excluded including fracture, thoracic outlet syndrome, brachial plexus disorders, referred neck pain, cervical radiculopathy, and advanced glenohumeral osteoarthritis (Evidence: pg no: 10, L421-L423)
Minimally limited or full shoulder range of motion (Evidence: pg no: 10, L426)

ONE OR MORE positive physical exam findings including O'Brien's Test, Biceps Load Test, Clunk Test, Anterior Slide Test, Compression Rotation Test, Speed's Test, Upper cut test, Popeye sign, Yergason's test, Proximal biceps (groove) tenderness (Evidence: pg no: 10, L427-L437)

exclusions: Any other indication or condition (Evidence: pg no: 10, L439-L440)

documentation: Function-limiting pain (Evidence: pg no: 10, L410-L412)

Failure of provider-directed non-surgical management for at least three (3) months in duration, except for discrete traumatic event resulting in acute proximal biceps tendon rupture (Evidence: pg no: 10, L413-L416)

Advanced diagnostic imaging study (e.g., MRI, CT) demonstrates labral tear/biceps tendon pathology (e.g., SLAP, Bankart, full-thickness subscapularis tear) and correlates with symptoms and physical exam findings (Evidence: pg no: 10, L417-L420)

Other potential pathological conditions have been excluded including fracture, thoracic outlet syndrome, brachial plexus disorders, referred neck pain, cervical radiculopathy, and advanced glenohumeral osteoarthritis (Evidence: pg no: 10, L421-L423)
Minimally limited or full shoulder range of motion (Evidence: pg no: 10, L426)

ONE OR MORE positive physical exam findings including O'Brien's Test, Biceps Load Test, Clunk Test, Anterior Slide Test, Compression Rotation Test, Speed's Test, Upper cut test, Popeye sign, Yergason's test, Proximal biceps (groove) tenderness (Evidence: pg no: 10, L427-L437)

exclusions: Any other indication or condition (Evidence: pg no: 10, L439-L440)

codes.description: Tenodesis of long tendon of biceps (Evidence: pg no: 13, L545)
Resection or transplantation of long tendon of biceps (Evidence: pg no: 13, L546)
Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; biceps tenodesis (Evidence: pg no: 14, L586)

full_source.notes: Conservative management exception for acute proximal biceps tendon rupture (Evidence: pg no: 10, L414-L416)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. full_source.description: Total hip arthroplasty (THA), also referred to as total hip replacement (THR), involves removal of the femoral head and acetabulum and placement of a prosthesis anchored to the bone. The goal of the procedure is long-term pain relief and restoration of function. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L746-L749)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses hip arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 22, L756-L757)

documentation: Primary and secondary tumors of the proximal femur (Evidence: pg no: 24, L837)
Hip fracture or complications including malunion, nonunion or failed prior fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L838)
Failed previous hip fracture fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L839)
Avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) with unresponsive severe pain (Evidence: pg no: 24, L840)
Revision of hip arthrodesis (Evidence: pg no: 24, L841)
Imaging evidence of significant joint destruction and cartilage loss, defined as Tönnis grade 3, modified Outerbridge grade III – IV, or Kellgren-Lawrence grade 3 – 4 (Evidence: pg no: 24, L844-L845)
Limited range of motion, antalgic gait and disabling pain of at least 3 months' duration (Evidence: pg no: 24, L846)
Pain with passive motion of the hip (Evidence: pg no: 24, L847)
Failure of at least 3 months of non-surgical conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 24, L848-L849)
Functional limitation secondary to hip pathology which interferes with the ability to perform age-appropriate daily activities (Evidence: pg no: 24, L850-L851)

exclusions: Indications for total hip arthroplasty other than those addressed in this guideline are considered not medically necessary (Evidence: pg no: 26, L937-L938)

codes.description: Arthroplasty, acetabular and proximal femoral prosthetic replacement (total hip arthroplasty), with or without autograft or allograft (Evidence: pg no: 27, L973-L974)

full_source.notes: All arthroplasty and acetabuloplasty/resection arthroplasty procedures are inclusive of synovectomy, removal of osteophytes, removal of loose bodies, manipulation of the hip, and release or repair of structures to gain entrance to the hip joint. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L749-L751)

full_source.description: Total hip arthroplasty (THA), also referred to as total hip replacement (THR), involves removal of the femoral head and acetabulum and placement of a prosthesis anchored to the bone. The goal of the procedure is long-term pain relief and restoration of function. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L746-L749)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses hip arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 22, L756-L757)

documentation: Primary and secondary tumors of the proximal femur (Evidence: pg no: 24, L837)
Hip fracture or complications including malunion, nonunion or failed prior fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L838)
Failed previous hip fracture fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L839)
Avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) with unresponsive severe pain (Evidence: pg no: 24, L840)
Revision of hip arthrodesis (Evidence: pg no: 24, L841)
Imaging evidence of significant joint destruction and cartilage loss, defined as Tönnis grade 3, modified Outerbridge grade III – IV, or Kellgren-Lawrence grade 3 – 4 (Evidence: pg no: 24, L844-L845)
Limited range of motion, antalgic gait and disabling pain of at least 3 months' duration (Evidence: pg no: 24, L846)
Pain with passive motion of the hip (Evidence: pg no: 24, L847)
Failure of at least 3 months of non-surgical conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 24, L848-L849)
Functional limitation secondary to hip pathology which interferes with the ability to perform age-appropriate daily activities (Evidence: pg no: 24, L850-L851)

exclusions: Indications for total hip arthroplasty other than those addressed in this guideline are considered not medically necessary (Evidence: pg no: 26, L937-L938)

codes.description: Arthroplasty, acetabular and proximal femoral prosthetic replacement (total hip arthroplasty), with or without autograft or allograft (Evidence: pg no: 27, L973-L974)

full_source.notes: All arthroplasty and acetabuloplasty/resection arthroplasty procedures are inclusive of synovectomy, removal of osteophytes, removal of loose bodies, manipulation of the hip, and release or repair of structures to gain entrance to the hip joint. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L749-L751)

documentation: Function-limiting pain (Evidence: pg no: 10, L410-L412)

exclusions: Any other indication or condition (Evidence: pg no: 10, L439-L440)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

documentation: Medical records documentation may be required to assess whether the member meets the clinical criteria for coverage (Evidence: pg no: 1, L40-L42)

exclusions: Unproven and not medically necessary due to insufficient evidence of efficacy (Evidence: pg no: 1, L37-L38)
full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

Indication: 
The patient is a 81 y.o. female who was brought to Greenwich Hospital Emergency Department after a mechanical fall 
after which the patient was unable to bear weight. X rays in the emergency room demonstrated evidence of a displaced 
femoral fracture. Given the nature of the injury, a discussion regarding the risks associated with and the alternatives to 
surgery were discussed. This discussion included the potential complications of deep venous thrombosis, infection, nerve 
or blood vessel injury, ligament injury, dislocation, leg length discrepancy, fracture, mal- or non-union, and incomplete 
resolution of pain, the patient wished to proceed with open reduction and intramedullary nailing of the femur.

Procedure: 
The patient was brought to the Operating Room and after the successful induction of spinal anesthesia, a closed 
reduction was performed. Flouroscopy was used to confirm that the reduction was within acceptable parameters. The 
lower extremity was then prepped and draped in the usual sterile manner with the patient in the supine position on the 
fracture table. Prophylactic antibiotics were administered within 30 minutes prior to the procedure as well as 1 gram of 
tranexamic acid. A time out was performed by all members of the surgical team confirming patient identity and surgical 
site laterality. 
A lateral incision was made proximal to, and in-line with, the femur. The entry guidewire was then advanced onto the 
appropriate start site on the greater trochanter. This was confirmed with intraoperative flouroscopy on both the AP and 
lateral views. The guidewire was then advanced with power into the intramedullary canal. Again flouroscopy was used to 
confirm that the entry guidewire was in the appropriate position. The entry reamer was then used through the soft tissue 
protector canula. Flouroscopy was used to confirm appropriate position of the entry reamer within the intramedullary canal 
and that it had been advanced to a sufficient depth. The reamer and entry guidewire were then removed. 
The nail was then carefully advanced over the guidewire. During advancement of the nail, all reduction maneuvers were 
employed to maintain the reduction during insertion of the nail. Flouroscopy was again used to confirm that the nail had 
been advanced to the appropriate depth. The long guidewire was then removed. An incision was made over the lateral 
aspect of the thigh and the cannula for the lag screw was advanced until it made contact with the lateral cortical bone. 
Using flouroscopic guidance, the guidewire for the lag screw was then inserted and confirmed to be in appropriate position 
with the guidwire center-center on AP and lateral views of the femoral head. The depth of the guidewire was then 
measured and the 95 mm lag screw selected. The guidewire was then overdrilled and tapped for the screw of the 
appropriate depth. The lag screw was then inserted to the appropriate depth which again confirmed using flouroscopy. 
We then turned our attention to insertion of the distal interlocking screw. A small incision was made over the lateral thigh 
in line with the cannula for the distal interlocking screw. The cannula was then advanced through the incision and down to 
bone. The drill was then carefully advanced and the depth of the interlocking screw measured off of the drill. The screw of 
appropriate length was then inserted. Flouroscopy was again used to confirm that the screws were in appropriate position. 
The wounds were then copiously irrigated. The fascia was closed with interrupted 0 vicryl suture. The deep subcutaneous 
layers were closed with interrupted 0 vicryl and the dermal layer with 3-0 vicryl. The skin was then closed with staples. 
Sterile dressings were then applied and the patient was awaken from anesthesia. The patient was transferred to the 
recovery room in stable condition. All sponge and instrument counts were correct. 
Postop Plan 
The patient will be WBAT (protected weight bearing with a walker). DVT prophylaxis will be started with aspirin starting 
POD1 additional DVT prophylaxis will include SCDs, compression stockings, progressive mobilization. They will receive 
24 hours of postoperative antibiotics. The patient will be discharged from the hospital when they are medically stable, 
have met all PT goals, and their pain is well controlled with oral analgesia. 
Kevin Choo, MD

extracted_info.summary: 81-year-old female admitted following a mechanical fall resulting in a comminuted intertrochanteric fracture of the right hip. key_information: Patient suffered mechanical fall with no loss of consciousness

procedure: Right hip open reduction internal fixation
Intramedullary nailing of the femur
extracted_info.summary: 81-year-old female who suffered a mechanical fall resulting in a displaced right intertrochanteric femur fracture. Patient underwent open reduction internal fixation with an Arthrex intramedullary nail (10mm short 130 degree nail, 95mm lag screw, 36mm interlocking screw). Procedure was performed under spinal anesthesia with an estimated blood loss of 150mL.
key_information: Surgery date: 10/09/2025
Surgeon: Dr. Kevin J Choo
Anesthesia: Spinal
EBL: 150mL
Implants: Arthrex Nail (10mm short 130 degree nail, 95mm lag screw, 36mm interlocking screw)
Post-op plan: WBAT (protected weight bearing with walker)
DVT prophylaxis: aspirin starting POD1, SCDs, compression stockings, progressive mobilization
24 hours of postoperative antibiotics
Tranexamic acid 1 gram administered during procedure
